articles.headline: Should U.S. Markets Be Wide Open?
articles.snippet: Looser regulation abroad poses risks to American investors while leaving U.S. stock markets at a new competitive disadvantage.
articles.abstract: Looser regulation abroad poses risks to American investors while leaving U.S. stock markets at a new competitive disadvantage.
articles.lead_paragraph: As markets globalize, the Securities and Exchange Commission is considering a fundamental change in regulatory philosophy that would make it possible for overseas brokerage firms to sell most foreign stocks directly to American investors, even if the companies do not comply with American disclosure rules.

articles.headline: Shrinking Pains at Kodak
articles.snippet: Eastman Kodak, tens of thousands of jobs lighter than it was three years ago, is struggling for a toehold in a competitive digital world.
articles.abstract: Eastman Kodak, tens of thousands of jobs lighter than it was three years ago, is struggling for a toehold in a competitive digital world.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, as the Eastman Kodak Company unveiled its long-anticipated consumer inkjet printer in New York, the mood at the company’s Rochester headquarters could not have been more positive.

articles.headline: Edwards Learns Blogs Can Cut 2 Ways
articles.snippet: Candidates could face problems as they try to integrate online political discourse into traditional campaigning.
articles.abstract: Candidates could face problems as they try to integrate online political discourse into traditional campaigning.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 — John Edwards learned the hard way this week of the perils of grafting the raucous culture of the Internet to the decidedly staider world of a presidential campaign.

articles.headline: Fox to Begin a ‘More Business Friendly’ News Channel
articles.snippet: Rupert Murdoch said the Fox Business Channel would be friendlier to corporations than CNBC, the leading TV business news outlet.
articles.abstract: Rupert Murdoch said the Fox Business Channel would be friendlier to corporations than CNBC, the leading TV business news outlet.
articles.lead_paragraph: No one has ever accused CNBC, the cable TV home of Jim Cramer, Larry Kudlow and Maria Bartiromo, of being antibusiness. Until now.

articles.headline: A Brutal Sport Is Having Its Day Again in Russia
articles.snippet: A form of dogfighting has thrived in Russia, cementing local legitimacy and gaining new followers.
articles.abstract: A form of dogfighting has thrived in Russia, cementing local legitimacy and gaining new followers.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Feb. 8 — The two opponents padded and paced on a snowcovered basketball court, waiting for their fight to begin.

articles.headline: Calm Before and During a Storm
articles.snippet: The calm demeanor of Timothy F. Geithner, the head of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, is being tested as he tries to monitor the $26 trillion credit derivatives market.
articles.abstract: The calm demeanor of Timothy F. Geithner, the head of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, is being tested as he tries to monitor the $26 trillion credit derivatives market.
articles.lead_paragraph: Timothy F. Geithner is 45, but he looks considerably younger, with an easy smile and hardly a wrinkle in sight.

articles.headline: Footballs, Funhouses and Fries
articles.snippet: Daniel M. Snyder, the entrepreneur and owner of the Washington Redskins, has agreed to acquire Johnny Rockets, the 1950s-inspired restaurant chain.
articles.abstract: Daniel M. Snyder, the entrepreneur and owner of the Washington Redskins, has agreed to acquire Johnny Rockets, the 1950s-inspired restaurant chain.
articles.lead_paragraph: Daniel M. Snyder, the entrepreneur and owner of the Washington Redskins, has agreed to acquire Johnny Rockets, the 1950s-inspired restaurant chain known for employees that sing and dance to vintage pop tunes every half-hour.

articles.headline: Shiite District, Flash Point in Baghdad, Rebuilds
articles.snippet: Sadr City, once infamous as a fetid slum and symbol of Shiite subjugation, is recovering. Many residents credit a Shiite militia, the Mahdi Army.
articles.abstract: Sadr City, once infamous as a fetid slum and symbol of Shiite subjugation, is recovering. Many residents credit a Shiite militia, the Mahdi Army.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Feb. 8 — Just past the main checkpoint into Sadr City, children kick soccer balls at goals with new green nets, on fields where mounds of trash covered the ground last summer. A few blocks away, city workers plant palm trees by the road, while men gather at a cafe nearby to chatter and laugh.

articles.headline: Accord Is Signed by Palestinians to Stop Feuding
articles.snippet: The agreement seemed to stop short of meeting the demands of the international community on Hamas.
articles.abstract: The agreement seemed to stop short of meeting the demands of the international community on Hamas.
articles.lead_paragraph: MECCA, Saudi Arabia, Feb. 8 — The main rival Palestinian factions agreed late Thursday to form a government of national unity aimed at ending a wave of violence between them and an international boycott.
